content:
Hi,

I have a question about the mcq "If A is a user-defined class and a is an instance of A, the expression type(a) == A evaluates to True." I was wondering what the difference between .isinstance(obj, class) and type is. Shown below, I set A to a parent class with subclass B and a as an instance of B. Evaluating type(a) == B resulted in True; isinstance(a, B) is True. However, type(a) == A is False and isinstance(a, A) is True. 

Would a still be considered an instance of the superclass A? If so, why would the answer to the mcq be True instead of False?

Thanks!
subject: Microquiz Multiple Choice Q
